Thank you.

post_text: Earlier this week, FIRST Robotics hosted an awards show to present the team awards for the regional competitions that were canceled for the 2020 season. These seasonal awards represent the FIRST ethos of "More than Robots" and highlight team achievements in promoting STEM and community engagement outside of the actual competition. I am proud to share with you that one of our team members, Alec Mierzejewski, was highlighted in this presentation as a Dean's List Finalist for the Central New York Regional. Alec was selected for his academic achievements, his leadership, and dedication to the team. He submitted an essay and mentor recommendation as well as participated in a video interview to earn this honor. While we did not get to compete with our robot, the team is very proud of our efforts this year and we are staying engaged through Google Classroom preparing for next year. Great job Alec, Team 5736, Mr. Hutchins and Mr. Kruse, all our adult mentors and sponsors, and the Robotics Booster Association on a great year and season!

post_text: On this date, 50 years ago (April 11, 1970) , Apollo 13 was launched from Kennedy Space Center. The mission was to land on the moon, collect samples and perform experiments, and then return back to Earth. The lunar landing was aborted after an oxygen tank in the service module (SM) failed two days into the mission, causing an explosion. A series of events and challenges followed that had never been foreseen, practiced, or planned for. There was no manual for this scenario. The mission quickly changed into a rescue mission, where NASA worked feverishly to save the three astronauts onboard and return them safely to Earth. More to follow later this week...

Maddie Canonico is a Junior at Kings Park High School. For the past two years she has been working on her Girl Scout Gold Award project. Her project is centered on the idea of equal access for deaf and hard of hearing people to emergency service. Some people cannot talk on the phone and therefore cannot communicate effectively with a 911 emergency service operator in an emergency. In the fall of 2018, Suffolk County released the text-to-911 program. Maddie wanted to help the county spread the word so more people would know about this new service. With the help of her friends, she set out to create a PSA video showing three scenarios where text-to-911 would be of vital importance for an individual who is deaf or hard of hearing. Recently, Maddie completed the video and her Gold Award project. You can access her video below. Well done Maddie!!!
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8Do8Oo8gOGI&t=2s

To achieve this, the magazine staff dedicated its time working to gather submissions of creative writing, such as poetry and prose; artwork, such as paintings and photography, and other visual arts media created by the student body. The staff evaluated the submitted works employing scholastic criteria in order to select the pieces published in this year’s magazine. They paired art, poetry, and prose with color and design to create a beautiful layout with creativity and style. The magazine’s success, in large part, is due to the immense talent of the student body, and the hard work and dedication of the Kaleidoscope staff.

post_text: This is yet another reason why I love working in Kings Park! Yesterday, over 40 dedicated members of KPY spent the day working on our JV Baseball Field. They donated their time and energy to improving the field and surrounding area. This past summer we tragically and suddenly lost a member of our Kings Park family, Michael McDermott. This work day was a great tribute to MM2. We are planning more work on the field later this year, and a special event in spring 2020. Thank you KPY Families for your time and efforts!

post_text: The Kings Park Superintendent’s Council had a great visit at Town of Smithtown Town Hall this morning. The students had the opportunity to take a tour of town hall and meet many of our elected officials. Special thanks to Supervisor Wehrheim, Council Woman Inzerillo, Councilman Lohmann, Vincent Puleo (Town Clerk), Susan DeHaven (Deputy Town Clerk), and Deanna Varricchio (Receiver of Taxes) for speaking with our students. The students had the opportunity to run a mock Town Board meeting, where they approved various items related to Kings Park. What a valuable learning experience for our students!
